rsbNotes.title: Ps 147
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 147 This is part of the great doxology that concludes the Psalter. It praises the Lord for rebuilding Jerusalem and was probably composed during the period of Judah’s restoration following its Babylonian captivity in the sixth century b.c. (Neh. 12:27–47). As in Ps. 146, God’s power is radically contrasted with human might.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:1
rsbNotes.text: 147:1 it is good. In this way the poet encourages the congregation to praise the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:2
rsbNotes.text: 147:2 gathers the outcasts. See introduction to this psalm. This verse probably refers to the return of Judeans to the Promised Land following Cyrus’s decree (2 Chr. 36:22, 23) that ended the Babylonian exile.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:4
rsbNotes.text: 147:4 the number of the stars. The number of stars seems infinite. Cf. Gen. 15:5.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:5
rsbNotes.text: 147:5 his understanding is beyond measure. God is above and beyond human intelligence. There is no scale that can measure infinity.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:8–9
rsbNotes.text: 147:8, 9 clouds . . . rain . . . grass . . . food. God regulates all the processes that provide food for His creatures.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:10
rsbNotes.text: 147:10 the legs of a man. God does not judge people by their physical strength or appearance, but according to their heart’s attitude toward Him (1 Sam. 16:7). Strong legs, like good horses, were important for soldiers.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:11
rsbNotes.text:
147:11 who fear him. See notes Ps. 34:7 and 36:1.

steadfast love. God’s covenant love for His people.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:13
rsbNotes.text: 147:13 the bars of your gates. The gates provide security for the city; note what happens when they are weak (Nah. 3:13).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:14
rsbNotes.text: 147:14 the finest of the wheat. Representative of fertility and provision.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:15
rsbNotes.text: 147:15 his word runs swiftly. It accomplishes its purpose quickly.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:19
rsbNotes.text: 147:19 his statutes and rules. He guides Israel in the proper way of corporate behavior.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 147:20
rsbNotes.text: 147:20 Praise the Lord. See v. 1.
